_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 
Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer management, property management, contractors plus all involved and affected tenants towards safe operation. In addition, some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its tenants and the surrounding communities. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer prepared a Chemical Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) in general accordance with federal regulations. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable substances. The federal regulations are codified in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 40, Section 68. Finally, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulates facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the PSM standards as defined in CCR, Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Part 1910, Section 119.

This program was updated to satisfy the required 5-year update and to make corrections as necessary. All elements have been reviewed and updated.

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including
    	administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4.	The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention st

eps
5.	The five-year accident history
6.	The emergency response program
7.	Planned changes to improve safety

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer is committed to complying with all the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

In the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the facility, refrigeration contractor personnel are trained in the appropriate mitigation measures, relying on emergency services provided by the fire department and the hazardous materials response team. Forum Clackamas Campus will continue to improve ammonia-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the RMP/PSM program.

All releases and near misses are recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored, and readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop policies and/or procedures that may prevent future incidents.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer facility is located at 9810 SE Mangan Way in Clackamas, Oregon. The facility is approximately 0.25 miles east of Interstate 205, and 1 mile south of the junction of Interstate 205 and Highway 224.  The immediate area is urban with primarily commercial and light residential areas.  The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia. The facility uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigeran

t within a closed system. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for freezer and dock operations. 

The quantity of ammonia in the process means that the system falls under the OSHA PSM regulations and as a result, are under the Program Level 3 regulations of the RMP regulations and submitted as such.

The RMP regulations require facilities to identify and evaluate chemical release scenarios resulting from potential failures of the chemical handling systems covered by the RMP. Program 3 facilities are required to evaluate a Worst-Case Release Scenario (release parameters are defined by the regulations) and an Alternative Release Scenario. The regulations define a Worst-Case Release Scenario as "...the greatest amount held in a single vessel...released as a gas over 10 minutes." An alternative release scenario is identified as a release that is more likely to occur at the facility.

This facility has prepared Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for both processes. These are not summarized herein as recommended by EPA but are presented in the RMP.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer prevention program is described in the RMP / PSM program.  The prevention program implemented by Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer Prevention Program are briefly described below:

Process Safety Information
Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer maintains current and complete refrigeration system technical information. The requirements of this section ensure that current and complete technical information is available to operating, maintenance and other individuals or tenants. The information

also serves as a resource for the Process Hazard Analysis team and may be used for many purposes, such as developing procedures and training programs. The compilation of written process safety information must be complete before conducting any process hazard analysis required by the standard.

Process Hazard Analysis
A process hazard analysis provides a thorough team evaluation of the ammonia refrigeration system. The purpose of performing a process hazard assessment is to discover, identify and address everything possible that can go wrong with the ammonia system and to then insert controls, thereby short-circuiting possible accidents.  

By studying the ammonia system through the consistent application of an established hazard analysis method, risks can be identified and prioritized. Current refrigeration science, historical accident information, industry lessons learned, and company and facility experience should be used in crafting a thorough analysis. These studies are powerful tools in reducing the likelihood and severity of system accidents. Natural and human cause external events were also considered in the process hazard analysis.

Operating Procedures
Procedures and policies are in place that establish how the refrigeration system is operated and maintained. Written operating procedures serve several purposes. First, established procedures can ensure that operators carry out jobs consistently and correctly, thereby avoiding dangerous mistakes.  Second, written procedures provide a means to communicate to individuals the proper way to perform tasks.  Finally, operators have access to information giving them guidance on how to respond to conditions. The standard operating procedures are periodically reviewed to ensure they reflect the current operating practices.

Mechanical Integrity
Prevention is the primary reason regular and scheduled inspection, testing, and maintenance is performed on the ammonia refrigeration system.  The systems inspection, testing

, and maintenance schedule shall follow industry RAGAGEP, manufacturer recommendations, and/or industry practice to help maintain the system.  The facility utilizes outside contractors to perform routine and emergency maintenance on the system.  

Incident Investigation
Written procedures and forms are in place detailing how and when the facility must investigate accidental / incidental releases. The facility investigates releases and near misses that could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia.  Recommendations are addressed and corrected by facility management. Completed reports are kept for five years and are reviewed as part of the process hazard analysis revalidation.

Training
Currently, the only individuals that carry out tasks in the refrigeration system are refrigeration contractor employees. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer must ensure the refrigeration contractor certifies operators following completion of operator training and confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned. Refrigeration operators are given initial training on hazards of anhydrous ammonia, an overview of the refrigeration system, and emergency operations to name a few. To ensure compliance with the procedures, refresher training is conducted as required. Where possible, training utilizes direct experience in the field to facilitate task understanding and address multiple learning methods.

Employee (Tenant) Participation
The purpose of the employee participation provisions is to ensure that tenants are involved in creating and maintaining the PSM program. Decisions as to which tenants / individuals will be consulted regarding specific PSM/RMP matters will consider factors such as job functions, experience, and degree of involvement with PSM/RMP, as well as their general background.  The following is required:
?	Tenants are made aware of ammonia as a part of their tenant package confirmation, in 
        conjunction with their companys hazard communication

program. 
?	Process Safety Information will be made available to all operators.
?	If applicable, at least one system operator who carry out daily rounds besides management 
        participates in any PHAs or revalidations.
?	Applicable PHA recommendations and documentation of actions taken will be available and 
        shared with tenants.
?	SOPs will be maintained readily accessible to individuals that may carry out tasks within the 
        ammonia refrigeration system. 
?	Individuals will be trained in safe work practices as applicable to their job duties.
?	Anyone involved in operating a process will be trained in 1) an overview of the process 2) the 
        operating procedures with an emphasis on hazards, 3) emergency operations including 
        shutdown, and 4) safe work practices. They must receive and understand the training. 
?	Anyone involved in maintaining a process will be trained in 1) an overview of the process and its 
        hazards 2) procedures applicable to their job tasks to ensure that they can perform the tasks in a 
        safe manner.
?	Each operator will be consulted with to determine the frequency of refresher training.
?	Each operator will be informed of changes to the system (MOCs) and trained in the change prior 
        to post-change startup.
?	Each employee who serves as a fire watch will be trained in fire watch duties including fire 
        extinguisher use.
?	Each incident investigation team shall have one team member knowledgeable in the 
        refrigeration system.
?	Incident investigation findings shall be reviewed with all affected personnel.
?	Tenants will be trained in their responsibilities under the Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer 
        emergency action plan as well as their companys emergency action plan.
?	Anyone with emergency response duties will be trained in their duties.
?	Compliance audits will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

Compliance Audit
The audit process is a valuable

tool to confirm Forum Clackamas Campus Freezers compliance with the RMP / PSM program and whether each of the elements in the prevention program has been implemented and properly documented. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer has established a Management System to address any shortcomings which the audit may find. A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for any changes or corrections.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The regulations require a review of the 5-year accident history at Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer. The history must include "all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage." (§68.42(a)). 

Based on the above definition, Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer assured no reportable release of ammonia had occurred during the past 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Action Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials, and other emergencies. Facility personnel shall coordinate with responding outside agencies. The facilities emergency action plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. Facility personnel will exchange data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. 

In addition, Fire Department personnel tour the facility frequently to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release. 

Currently, on-site personnel do not enter an atmospheric concentration of 25 ppm for anhydrous ammonia. Facility personnel will assist the refrigeration contractor and outside agencies in a plant advisory role for releases exceeding 25 ppm. The plan for all releases is the safety of the tenants employees, isolating an

d keeping personnel out of the affected area, and internal notifications and external notifications where necessary. All personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Tenants / employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility. Several PHA studies have been conducted, and the study teams have made recommendations for improved safety. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer will respond to all suggested mitigation measures promptly. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer has established completion schedules for proposed actions. Management responses and support will be consistent with Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations.

Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer recognizes that the RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements / modifications to the RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Forum Clackamas Campus Freezer's internal review practices and will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version RMP / PSM and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies.

The recommendation lists include scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.
